meta_data.title: We Kept Receipts!
meta_data.subtitle: Nehemiah 2:4-8 Thanks to everyone who supports TMBH at  You're the reason we can all do this together!  Music by

transcription_data.text: Every single last one of you, I mean every single last one of you is a lucky lucky boy girl, because today on this very podcast we're gonna talk about ancient Persian receipts! That's right, that's about to happen. Don't turn it off. Why are you being all weird about it? Do you think, come on, it's gonna be more interesting than it sounds like. Sometimes if you make things sound real hypey and you yell and bring the energy then people are like that boring thing suddenly sounds awesome. You didn't fall for it, fine. Let me try logic to sell you on why this is gonna be interesting. Because every single time that we have any physical artifact that we can hold in our hand from 2,500 years ago that connects us to any other world, other time in history that is now mostly lost, that's a big deal. But when we have artifacts in our hand that tell us little details about the comings and goings of the world that we're reading about in the Bible from 2,500 years ago, I think that gets even interesting, and we have that kind of situation here as we get a little peek into what the economic life was like of the court of King Artaxerxes in Persia and how in a practical sense, Artaxerxes was gonna have to make moves to grant the request that Nehemiah is making in chapter two. Was that better? I'm not sure that was better. I don't know, it's gonna be good. Here's what we're doing. Nehemiah chapter two, we got a situation where Nehemiah has received a dreadful message. His ancestral homeland is in disrepair. The people are in disgrace and are in need of rebuilding and the walls and the gates are in disrepair and they're in need of rebuilding. So he thinks about it for a long time, maybe months even. And then in March of 444 BC, we think on one fateful day, he goes into the throne room to bring wine to the king and however he makes it clear that he's not doing very well, it comes through to the emotionally attentive king. He's like, hey man, what's up? I've never seen you sad in my presence before. What's going on? Okay, that's a good start. Nehemiah is like, I'm sad because of this stuff that's going on that I just said a minute ago about disgrace and walls being busted down and everything. And then the king gives him a positive response. He's like, well, what is it that you want? The Nehemiah gathers himself, breathes, thinks for a minute, prays to God. And then he says, if it pleases the king and if your servants found favor in the king's sight, then let the king send me to the city in Judah where my fathers are buried so I can rebuild it. Then the king with the queen sitting beside him asked me, how long will your journey take and when will you get back? Okay, so that's a yes. We're no longer in the negotiating thumbs up, thumbs down phase of this conversation. Now we're into the, what's it gonna take to get this right? What do you need part of the conversation? And Nehemiah picks up on that. And verse nine, he says in response to that question from the king, how long will your journey take? And when will you get back? And Nehemiah says, it pleased the king to send me. So I set a time. Okay, great. Verse seven, I also said to him, now we're getting to the fine details of the negotiation. If it pleases the king, may I have letters to the governors of trans-Eufrates so that they will provide me safe conduct until I arrive in Judah? Interesting for a lot of reasons. Okay, one, remember what we found in the book of Ezra? Nehemiah's contemporary who went a few years earlier to go and try and rebuild the people and get the sacrificial system working right. And then he ran into societal rot there that he tried to root out maybe in an advisable way, maybe in a not advisable way, Jerry's still out on that. Remember, Ezra made that trip with a crazy amount of money, but he declined an escort from this same very king. Whoa, okay, well, I wonder if Artis Ruxi still has that in his mind. Yeah, I seem to remember another one of you types coming in here and wanting to go to Jerusalem to do things. And I gave the thumbs up on that. I wasn't quite sure what the protocol was with you, Nehemiah because this other fellow, what was it? Ezra, yeah, Ezra. He declined a military escort. So Nehemiah starts by addressing that question that might have been lingering for Artis Ruxis. Like, do you want people with swords to make sure you get there? Cause I really like you to get there and back. You're really useful to me. I kind of like having you around. I'd prefer if you didn't die also. You're probably gonna have a lot of my money. So Nehemiah just pops that tension bubble. And so it's like, yeah, I'd love to have letters to the governors of Trans-Uphrades so that I can be provided with this safe conduct all the way to Judah. Ezra, you'll recall, it looked like his game plan was to say, I am so connected to the grand big narrative of the whole story of what you and I call the Old Testament, the whole story of the Hebrew, Jewish, Israelite people that I believe that the providence of God is on this. I'm so sure of it that I don't want to betray that confidence by telling the king that I'll accept a military escort. So I'm just gonna shrewdly divide it up amongst my guys and then we will go and I think I'm right about God wanting this to work out. And then of course, Ezra gets there with this plan that I'm not sure was advisable. I still don't know what to make of it. So Ezra divides up all this huge mountain of money between all these different guys. They all make the trip and you'll recall that when they got there to Jerusalem and they all turned out their pockets, every penny was accounted for. That in itself is kind of a miracle, amazing, right? Well, the plan's gonna be different here on this trip. Nehemiah's like, let's just do it the normal way where you give swords and huge guys and stuff and where all of the people through whose set traps I will be traveling. I don't know why that sentence was hard for me, but it was. Let's make sure that all of them have clear instructions from you, the king with the full weight of your authority behind it saying, make sure this guy gets to where he's going faster. Now the king wouldn't like that as well because it means, I mean, the safer trip is a faster trip. You don't want your guy getting way laid. You wanted to get there and get back as quickly as possible so that he can be in a better mood when he serves you wine. That's not the full motivation of our dessert, because he's, but yeah, I think you know what I mean. Okay, so let's take stock of the request so far. I'm sad and I would like to feel better. Cool, what's wrong? The stuff is broken in my city. I'd like to go do something about it. Okay, great. How long is the journey going to take? Oh, okay, it's going to take about this long. When do you want to go? Well, this is about when I want to go. Do you want your trip to look like the way Ezra did it or do you have something else in mind? No, I'd like to do it more in the official Kingly representative of the throne way. Okay, great. And now we're on to the next part of this request for the nuts and bolts of how this trip is actually going to work. Verse eight, Nehemiah is still talking here. And may I have letters to Asaph, keeper of the king's forest. So he will make me timber to make beams for the gates of the Citadel by the temple and for the city wall and for the residents, I will occupy every resource in Persia belongs to the king. Remember Herodotus spells it out a bunch of different times most famously in the interaction between the Persian legate and King Leonidas of Sparta. But Herodotus tells us a whole bunch that the Persians had this habit of going to places. I mean, like, you know, what would be way cooler than coming in here with a giant cosmopolitan army with people wearing costumes from the rest of the world and killing you slowly with all of their different interesting weapons and interesting ways would be way more fun. Is if you just bottled up a little bit of your water and a little bit of your dirt and you gave it to this Persian representative right here and he just took it back to the great king of kings and was like, hey, this town, Benthene to you here is their earth and water. You are in charge, their resources are now yours. You are now responsible, oh great king for their care. That's the deal. You guys want to do that? Because that would be way easier than the stabbing and most people were like, great, we'd love to be Persian, Persian is awesome. Some people like the Greeks famously Spartan kicked somebody into a giant pit. I don't know, they actually did exactly that. But they said, no, we're not giving you the gift of earth and water, you don't own us. Well, in Trans-U-Fraidys, the land beyond the river where Jerusalem is, the great king of kings had on his shelf labeled earth and water. I got from people instead of having to kill them who decided to take the easy way that I put here on this shelf. On his shelf, he had one of those jars that's labeled Jerusalem. So all the trees around there, they belong to the king, the water that flows through there, that belongs to the king, the dirt that all the houses are built on, that belongs to the king. So Nehemiah can't just go and show up and be like, all right, we're taking these trees without a receipt. He needs some sort of imperial regal order, the proper paperwork to say, this many trees are to be cut down or supply whatever trees are needed from the king's forest to this man to complete said project. And there ends the throne room exchange between Artaxerxes and Nehemiah with Queen Demaspia sitting by. And in addition to how this dovetails in with the last such journey and request with Ezra and a whole bunch of other big picture theology things that we'll work through, this is also super fun because of the receipts, because we can picture, you can hold in your hand. I mean, you have to break into a place and smash glass and I'm sure you'd get a ton of trouble or maybe you could file some sort of requisition to get to hold it, probably you're never gonna get to hold it. But theoretically it is possible to physically hold the receipts, the work orders, the marching orders that would set into motion all of this stuff that the king was going to grant because we've got a mountain of these things that have been discovered dating back to the reign of Cyrus and dating forward long beyond the reign of Artaxerxes. The Persians did a really good job of keeping track of this expansive, bureaucratically governed empire where every single thing that was in the empire was owned by the king and controlled by the king. And overwhelmingly the king paid people in resources not coin. And tomorrow we're gonna talk more about specifically what that looked like. I'm gonna tell you where you can go and look at these things for yourself. It's not easy. They're not readily available all over the internet. You gotta want to find them, but I'm gonna show you where to get them. So you can go and look at these with your own eyes and consider if you might be looking on one of the receipts from this particular journey of Nehemiah, because you might be. And I think that's super fun. And then we'll work a little bit further forward in the text as well to see how these various officials felt when they got these receipts, when they got these marching orders and work orders from the king. I love it when the Bible story and the extra biblical stuff intersects is just super fun to chase that down. And if you happen to be one of the people who listen, who does not find that to be as fun as me, then I owe you a big thank you. This thank you for indulging me on this and letting me have super fun with this particular intersection and share my joy over it with you more on that tomorrow. I'm Matt, this is the 10 Minute Bible Hour podcast. Let's do this again soon.
